Before we beginâ€¦ yes, we know.
DuckDB is OLAP. KeraDB is OLTP.
One is built to slice through massive analytical datasets like a lightsaber.
The other is optimized for fast, tiny transactional operations.

This benchmark is not a fair fight â€” and we knew that.
But developers kept asking questions, and curiosity got the best of us.
So we ran it anyway using Rustâ€™s criterion.rs benchmarking suite.

And in the spirit of DuckDB:
Quack quack. ğŸ¦†
Let's see what happened.

Quick Summaryâ€‹

Despite being an OLAP engine, DuckDB held its own in range scans, while KeraDB â€” as expected â€” dominated on OLTP-style operations such as inserts, updates, deletes, point lookups, mixed workloads, and JSON-heavy tasks.

In other words:

  • When the workload looks like â€œgive me a bunch of rows, now!â€ â†’ DuckDB shines.
  • When the workload looks like â€œinsert, update, lookup, deleteâ€¦ repeat fast!â€ â†’ KeraDB zooms.

This test confirms what we already suspected â€” and reveals where each engineâ€™s internal design flexes its muscles.

DuckDB excels in exactly what it was designed for:

When we hit it with OLTP-style micro-operations (single inserts, updates, point lookups), it politely responded with:

And of course: being a duck that quacks loudly in analytics.

entry.title: KeraDB Is Now Available on PyPI
entry.summary: We're excited to share that KeraDB is now available on PyPI, making it easy to use KeraDB directly in Python applications.
entry.content:
We're excited to share that KeraDB is now available on PyPI, making it easy to use KeraDB directly in Python applications.

You can now install KeraDB with a single command:

pip install keradb

This release makes KeraDB accessible to Python developers building local-first apps, agents, data tools, and embedded systems that need fast document storage and vector search without running an external database.

With the PyPI release, KeraDB can now be used directly inside Python projects for:

  • Embedded document storage
  • Fast single-record CRUD operations
  • Local-first and offline workflows
  • AI/agent pipelines that need lightweight persistence
  • Prototyping without database setup or servers

KeraDB runs as an embedded database, so there's no service to manage and no configuration required to get started.

Quick Exampleâ€‹

from keradb import KeraDB

db = KeraDB("example.kdb")

db.insert("users", {
    "id": "user_1",
    "name": "Alice",
    "role": "developer"
})

user = db.get("users", "user_1")
print(user)

The API is intentionally simple and document-first, designed to feel natural in Python while retaining KeraDB's low-latency core.

Get Startedâ€‹

  • PyPI: https://pypi.org/project/keradb/
  • Documentation: https://keradb.github.io/docs
  • GitHub: https://github.com/KeraDB/keradb

If you're building something with KeraDB in Python, we'd love to hear about it.

entry.title: KeraDB vs RocksDB Benchmark (v0.1.0) â€” Yes, We Got Destroyedâ€¦ For Now

entry.content:
This post shares our KeraDB vs RocksDB benchmark results, and letâ€™s just say it upfront:
RocksDB absolutely outperformed us in most categories.

But thatâ€™s okay.

Because RocksDB has:

  • 10+ years of optimization,
  • dozens of Facebook engineers behind it,
  • and billions of production workloads tuning it daily.

KeraDB has:

  • one maintainer with coffee,
  • dreams,
  • and version v0.1.0.

So yes â€” RocksDB is faster. But KeraDB is just getting started, and this benchmark gives us a map for where to improve next.
(Also: we did win one category. Let us enjoy that.)

All benchmarks come from our Criterion.rs suite.

Quick Comparisonâ€‹

CategoryWinnerPerformance Advantage
Single InsertRocksDB~5Ã— faster
Point QueryRocksDB~6.8Ã— faster

Mixed Read/Write (80/20)RocksDB~4.5Ã— faster

Bulk Insert (100 docs)KeraDB~7Ã— faster (our one glorious win)
Bulk Insert (â‰¥1k docs)RocksDB1.05â€“4.2Ã— faster
UpdatesRocksDB~1.35Ã— faster

TL;DR: RocksDB won almost every round except the first 100-doc bulk insert test, where KeraDB stood tall and said:
"Not today, giant."

Soâ€¦ Why Did RocksDB Win So Hard?â€‹

RocksDB is basically the final form of an LSM-tree database:

  • highly optimized write paths,
  • background compaction,
  • lightning-fast key-range iteration,
  • efficient prefix scanning,
  • production-grade caches and bloom filters.

Meanwhile, KeraDB is intentionally simple today:

  • no compaction,
  • no write-ahead log,
  • no tiered storage,
  • no bloom filters,
  • no column families,
  • no LSM treeâ€¦ yet.

Weâ€™re playing checkers while RocksDB is playing 6D chess.

Where KeraDB Still Shinesâ€‹

Even in v0.1.0, KeraDB has early strengths:

  • Low dependency footprint â€” pure Rust, no native bindings
  • Simple, document-first API
  • Fast small-batch inserts (100 docs)
  • Predictable, clean codebase thatâ€™s easy to evolve
  • Native JSON/document storage without schema overhead

And most importantly:

KeraDB isnâ€™t trying to be RocksDB.

At least not yet.

KeraDB is built for:

  • embedded AI agents
  • local-first apps
  • edge workloads
  • vector search
  • document-centric micro-databases

These workloads value simplicity and flexibility, not raw LSM-tree throughput.

The Road Ahead (a.k.a. Our Villain Arc Begins)â€‹

Based on these results, hereâ€™s what weâ€™re improving next:

Coming Soonâ€‹

  • Range scan optimization
  • Write batching
  • Early compaction strategies
  • Optional WAL mode
  • Prefix-based iteration
  • Better on-disk layout for sequential scans
  • Optimized delete paths

Coming Laterâ€‹

  • A lightweight LSM-tree variant
  • Configurable storage engines
  • Bloom filters
  • Caching layers
  • Column families

In short:
v0.2.x and v0.3.x are going to be spicy.

Final Thoughtsâ€‹

RocksDB is still the heavyweight champion of embedded key-value stores â€” as it should be.
KeraDB is the new challenger, still stretching, still sipping pre-workout.

But benchmarks like this give us the roadmap to get stronger.

Weâ€™ll get faster.
Weâ€™ll get smarter.
Weâ€™ll absolutely close these gaps.

And one day â€” maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow â€” KeraDB will run this rematch.

Stay tuned.

entry.content:
This post summarizes the results of our v0.1.0 benchmark comparison between KeraDB, an embedded NoSQL + vector search database, and SQLite, the widely used embedded relational engine.
The goal is to highlight the strengths of each system and provide transparency on where KeraDB excels todayâ€”and where we plan to optimize next.

All results are taken from our Criterion.rs benchmark suite.

Quick Comparisonâ€‹

CategoryWinnerNotes

Point QueryKeraDB (~5Ã— faster)Hash-based lookup; no query parser

Mixed Read/Write (80/20)KeraDB (~63Ã— faster)Optimized for interactive workloads
Delete (100 docs)KeraDB (2Ã— faster)Low overhead for small batches
Bulk Inserts (5,000 docs)SQLite (~4Ã— faster)Transaction batching efficiency
Range QueriesSQLite (7â€“39Ã— faster)Optimized B-tree sequential scanning
Storage ThroughputSQLite (~10Ã— faster)WAL + batched disk sync advantages

Interpretationâ€‹

Where KeraDB Excelsâ€‹

KeraDB consistently dominates in low-latency, document-centric operations:

  • Very fast single inserts and point queries
  • High performance for nested/complex JSON
  • Excellent under mixed read/write workloads
  • Strong small-batch deletion performance
  • Zero configuration and native document formats

These characteristics make KeraDB ideal for:

  • Local-first applications
  • Edge/agent workflows
  • AI pipelines and LLM tooling
  • Apps working heavily with JSON documents
  • Workloads needing predictable sub-100Âµs response times

Where SQLite Excelsâ€‹

SQLite remains exceptional for relational batch operations and large sequential scans:

  • Bulk inserts scale extremely well with transactions
  • Range queries are significantly faster
  • Write-ahead logging provides strong bulk throughput
  • SQL-based analytics remain unmatched

SQLite is still the better fit for:

  • Analytical queries
  • High-volume batch ingestion
  • Heavy use of LIMIT/OFFSET style iteration
  • Relational schemas and SQL flexibility

Whatâ€™s Next for KeraDBâ€‹

Based on the benchmark profile, our upcoming optimization areas include:

  • Improving range scan performance
  • Adding cursor-based iteration
  • Exploring lazy/lite document deserialization
  • Optional batched write mode
  • Reduced overhead for large result sets

These improvements will be part of our upcoming releases.

Final Thoughtsâ€‹

KeraDB and SQLite serve different workloads well:

  • If your application is document-first, JSON-heavy, or latency-critical â†’ KeraDB is shaping up to be a strong choice.
  • If you need SQL, batch-heavy writes, or analytical scans â†’ use SQLite for now.

Weâ€™ll continue publishing benchmark updates as KeraDB evolves.

If you have ideas, feedback, or would like to contribute, feel free to open a discussion or issue in our GitHub repo.

entry.title: Introducing KeraDB
entry.summary: We're thrilled to announce the official launch of KeraDB â€” a lightweight, embedded database with MongoDB-compatible APIs and built-in vector search capabilities.
entry.content:
We're thrilled to announce the official launch of KeraDB â€” a lightweight, embedded database with MongoDB-compatible APIs and built-in vector search capabilities.

Why KeraDB?â€‹

Building modern applications often requires a database, but not every project needs the complexity of running a separate database server. Whether you're prototyping a new idea, building an Electron app, or developing an AI application that needs vector similarity search, KeraDB provides a simple, powerful solution.

Key Featuresâ€‹

  • MongoDB-Compatible SDK â€” If you know MongoDB, you already know KeraDB. Our familiar query syntax means zero learning curve.

  • Embedded & Serverless â€” No separate database process to manage. Your database lives right alongside your application.

  • Vector Search Built-in â€” Perfect for AI/ML applications. Store and query embeddings with efficient similarity search.

  • Multi-Language Support â€” Available for Node.js, Python, and Rust with consistent APIs across all platforms.

  • Lightweight & Fast â€” Written in Rust for maximum performance with minimal footprint.

Getting Startedâ€‹

Getting up and running takes just a few lines of code:

const { KeraDB } = require('keradb');

const db = new KeraDB('./myapp.db');
const users = db.collection('users');

await users.insertOne({ 
  name: 'Alice', 
  email: 'alice@example.com' 
});

const user = await users.findOne({ name: 'Alice' });

What's Next?â€‹

This is just the beginning. We're actively working on:

  • Enhanced vector search algorithms
  • Additional language SDKs
  • Performance optimizations
  • More query operators

Join the Communityâ€‹

We'd love to hear from you! Check out our documentation to get started, and don't hesitate to:

  • Star us on GitHub
  • Report issues or request features
  • Join the conversation

Thank you for being part of the KeraDB journey. We can't wait to see what you build!

â€” The KeraDB Team
